oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An Ordinance Against Being Drunk
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small broadside announcing that it shall be a misdemeanor for any person to be drunk on the public square, on the street, or in any public place. Fine not to exceed $50.00. Endorsed by Mayor J.M. Wilson and Clerk W.C. Morgan.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Announcements; Handbills; Fliers (printed matter); Plazas; Intoxication; Temperance
Broadsides; Lincoln County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: With the founding in 1874 of the Women's Christian Temperance Union (WCTU), the temperance movement in the United States showed steady growth into the next century. Anti-alcohol posters and broadsides proliferated throughout this period.
